fields.description:
We use Jira Agile OnDemand and have BitBucket repos.

We use Smart commits in our Commit comments, eg

MYISSUE-5 #comment This is a comment #time 1h

In the last week or so I have noticed that Jira Agile is no longer applying #time references in the commit messages, hence not applying any Worklogs to and Jira issues (see attached image)

This is affecting our timesheet tracking and worklogs.

What is the problem?

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h4. Scenario:
* OnDemand customer using SVN+FeCru
* Makes use of [smart commits|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AOD/Processing+JIRA+issues+with+commit+messages] to add comments to issues through commit messages
* Wants to migrate to Bitbucket due to [FishEye OnDemand end-of-life|http://go-dvcs.atlassian.com/display/EOL/Source+Review+Bundle+End+of+Service]
* Follows the instructions we provide at http://go-dvcs.atlassian.com/display/aod/Migrating+from+Subversion+to+Git+on+Bitbucket

h4. Problem:
When they successfully migrate to Bitbucket and the DVCS Connector synchronises with their migrated repos for the first time, it will re-process those smart commits again. This means they will get duplicate comments added to their existing JIRA issues. This could potentially be worse than extra comments -- it could be extra work logged or a re-opened issue being closed again.
fields.summary: Migrating from OnDemand's SVN+FeCru to Bitbucket+DVCS Connector can result in duplicated entities from smart commits

Cheers

fields.description:
Hi,
I have installed JIRA 6.0.3 and tried to sync GitHub using the DVCS Connector. Ther very first sync worked very well, however, if I try to sync my repo manually I get the following error message:
{code}
  Sync Failed: There was a SQL exception thrown by the Active Objects library: Database: - name:Microsoft SQL Server - version:10.00.1600 - minor version:0 - major version:10 Driver: - name:jTDS Type 4 JDBC Driver for MS SQL Server and Sybase - version:1.2.4 java.sql.SQLException: Invalid column name *.   –  
{code}

I already tried the instructions [here | https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/JIRA+DVCS+Plugin+Install+Fails+after+Upgrade], but the problem keeps happening.

How can I get the repo to sync from now?

Thanks for your help,
fields.summary: Sync Failed - Invalid column name" *

fields.description:
Issue cloned from https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/GHC-9

- Go to the Configure GitHub Repositories screen
- Select a project (make sure it is not the first one)
- Type an incorrect url on the textbox (for example, misstype "github")
- Click on "Add Repository"

*Expected*: Error message to show, user to be able to fix the url and click Add Repository

*Actual*: Error message is shown, however, the dropdown boxes reset to select the first project on the list. User is unlikely to notice, will fix the url and be surprised that the repo got added to the wrong project.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
- Add public bitbucket repo
- Add the post-commit hook to the repository
- Commit and push a changeset with a valid issue key on message
- Navigate to the issue and open the bitbucket tab

*Expected*: New commit to appear
	
*Actual*: Commit does not appear.

Notes
- After 10 minutes of refreshing and waiting for the commit I force synced and the commits appeared.
- This may be related to DCON-43, if there is a failure to connect to bitbucket at the moment the post-commit occurred, the commits will be effectively lost until a force sync.
fields.summary: BitBucket post commit hook does not trigger a re-sync of commit data

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Hello,
One of our clients is using JIRA 6 and DVCS 1.3.1.1. Recently, we've been having stability issues with the DVCS plugin.
Basically, here is what is happening:
1. DVCS generates a SQL Query on the database
2. This query, for some reason, gets "stuck" and therefore blocks all the following queries
3. This makes the DB Connection Pool quickly full and eventually JIRA crashes.

Since I've deactivated DVCS the issue didn't happen again, that is why I believe the root-cause is the DVCS plugin. The SQL query that *always* blocks all the others is the following:
{code}
SELECT * FROM jiraschema.AO_E8B6CC_CHANGESET_MAPPING WHERE SMARTCOMMIT_AVAILABLE =  @P0   ORDER BY DATE DESC
{code}

We are using JIRA 6.0.3 and DVCS 1.3.1.1 and SQL Server 10.50.4000 database.

Can you please let me know how this can be fixed? 
Also, I wanted to upgrade to 1.4.0.1 to see if it would fix the issue, but I cannot do that because of DCON-330.

Thanks for your help,
fields.summary: SQL query keeps blocking all the others

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. ***Current Behavior***
Newly created users do not receive BitBucket invites when automatic access is configured.

h3. ***Expected Behavior***
Newly created users receives BitBucket invites when automatic access is configured.

h3. ***Steps to Reproduce***
# Log into JIRA as a user with administrative rights.
# Navigate to the JIRA Admin pages.
# Choose DVCS Accounts from the Add-ons section.
# The Manage DVCS Accounts page displays. 
# Locate the account to configure.
# Press the settings  icon and choose Configure automatic access from the menu. The Configure automatic access dialog appears. It lists the groups for the Bitbucket account.
# Select the groups you want new users assigned to.
# Press Save.
# Create a new user in JIRA
fields.summary: Configure Automatic Team Invites is not Functioning

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
The fix introduced for DCON-190 changed the where clause in a way that breaks PostgreSQL databases.

A proper fix to this issue involves not performing the query *at all* if the project in question has no repository mappings. We should *not* be issuing a database query that we know will return zero rows in the first place.

fields.description:
When using the #time smart commit directive: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BITBUCKET/Processing+JIRA+issues+with+commit+messages 

Awesome feature! But...If you include decimal values as part of a commit message to Bitbucket, such as “#time 1.5h”, the time worked gets parsed incorrectly into JIRA.

Commit with "#time 1.5h" and JIRA logs 5 hours of work with “.1 “ prepended to the commit comment in the work log. Yes, you read this right – it not only loses the decimal value, it reverses it in the process. So a 1.5 hours logged becomes 5 hours logged.

The work-around is either use a whole value (“#time 90m”) or provide the value in parts (“#time 1h 30m”).

On the positive side, my coworkers have been impressed with my 24+ hour workdays (that is until we figured out the issue ;-)
fields.summary: Smart commit #time with decimal values parses incorrectly

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Software Server*. Using *JIRA Software Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSWCLOUD-14061].
  {panel}

When a synchronization takes a long time to run in {{RepositoryServiceImpl.syncRepositoryList}}, it occupies the {{SYNC_REPOSITORY_LIST_LOCK}} for synching repositories (for all organizations). This would block subsequent syncs that need to enter the same code block, even for syncs for other organizations.

One example of the long running-ness is due to a long running SELECT query in DCON-425.

This issue could cause all (the four) clustered scheduler threads to be used up by the DVCS Connector, thus no other clustered scheduled tasks could be run.

There are a few things to improve here:
# The sync should be moved outside of the scheduler thread
#* The scheduler thread should be just kicking off the sync and immediately return to free up the thread for other scheduler jobs.
# The {{SYNC_REPOSITORY_LIST_LOCK}} is too exclusive.
#* It could be applied to per organization, instead of to the whole DB
# The attempt to lock should timeout, once we change the lock to be per org
#* When the lock is occupied, it means that previous sync is still running.
#* We need to be careful when we extend the sync period dynamically.
fields.summary: Long running synchronization initiation blocks subsequent scheduled syncs and other scheduled tasks

fields.description:
This has been noticed recently that the "Invalid user/team account" error message gets thrown when there is not enough memory to sync the DVCS connector to a large repository. The problem with this error message is that it seems to be a "Catch All" for a whole bunch of different problems, ranging from wrong Java version and restricted firewall rule to a real "Invalid user/team account" like what the error message is actually saying.

{panel:title=Workaround| borderStyle=dashed| borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}

Upping the *memory* in JIRA has been seen to solve this problem, [see here for more|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Increasing+JIRA+Memory]. It was noticed for example when trying to sync with GitHub.

Reconfiguring *firewall* to allow connection also seems to be a solution, noticed when trying to connect to Bitbucket.

There are also some other problems that might cause this same error. Please see [DVCS Connector won't connect to GitHub, returns Invalid User/Team Account|https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=387449208] for further information.

Above all, if you are an OnDemand customer, or the steps in the above KB articles do not work for you, *_please contact Atlassian Support_* at https://support.atlassian.com.

{panel}
fields.summary: DVCS Connector throws Invalid user/team account if there is not enough memory

- Sync the repo on both clients

*Expected*: a) Second sync to show error message stating that a sync is in progress, b) Both syncs to finish showing the same status message and all commits synced properly

*Actual*: Each client shows a different commit count.

Notes:
- What is harder to verify is if we missed any commit from being stored, I didn't see a case where a commit was missing from a bug. 
- One of the windows shows a 500 internal server error on the script.
- I tried this scenario several times, and there were 2 different exceptions that where shown on the log (I attach both of them).
- Some times the count was less than the actual number of commits and sometimes more.
fields.summary: Error in sync summary count and exception in log when syncing the same repo from two clients at the same time

fields.description:
h6.summary
If a transition has a Post Function to send a notification to HipChat, it will fail when it's triggered by a DVCS trigger ([Configuring workflow triggers|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Configuring+workflow+triggers]), it will fail.

h6.steps to reproduce
# set up DVCS and HipChat integrations in JIRA; 
# edit a workflow transition and add to it:
#* a trigger, e.g. 'Branch created';
#* a 'Notify HipChat' Post Function,
and save and publish the workflow;
# in an issue using the workflow, click *Create branch* in the Development panel.

*Expected result:* new branch is created, the issue is transitioned, and a HipChat notification is sent.

*Actual result:* new branch is created, but the transition isn't executed.

Erros in JIRA logs:
{noformat}2015-02-13 16:02:54.359267500 2015-02-13 16:02:54,356 DVCSConnector.EventService:thread-1 ERROR sysadmin 1243x10424x1 x1kfb4 46.243.25.78,131.103.26.161 /secure/admin/AddBitbucketOrganization!finish.jspa [atlassian.jira.workflow.OSWorkflowManager] Caught exception while attempting to perform action 41 from workflow 10507 on issue 'WB-3'
2015-02-13 16:02:54.359269500 java.lang.NullPointerException
2015-02-13 16:02:54.359270500 	at com.atlassian.labs.jira.workflow.HipChatPostFunction.execute(HipChatPostFunction.java:75)
2015-02-13 16:02:54.359270500 	at com.opensymphony.workflow.AbstractWorkflow.executeFunction(AbstractWorkflow.java:1050)
2015-02-13 16:02:54.359287500 	at com.opensymphony.workflow.AbstractWorkflow.transitionWorkflow(AbstractWorkflow.java:1446)
2015-02-13 16:02:54.359287500 	at com.opensymphony.workflow.AbstractWorkflow.doAction(AbstractWorkflow.java:564)
{noformat}

{noformat}2015-02-13 16:02:54.438269500 2015-02-13 16:02:54,436 DVCSConnector.EventService:thread-1 ERROR sysadmin 1243x10424x1 x1kfb4 46.243.25.78,131.103.26.161 /secure/admin/AddBitbucketOrganization!finish.jspa [triggers.impl.transition.WorkflowTriggerTransitionProcessor] aae6b897-18ee-4f8c-9ea4-de475a4b6a5b Failed to perform transition 41 for issue WB-3: Errors: {}
2015-02-13 16:02:54.438272500 Error Messages: [null]
{noformat}

(full messages here: [^trigger_log_errors.log])

JIRA UI doesn't display any errors, but when viewing the workflow, go to the affected transition, and in the _Trigger_ tab click *View details* to see the failed transition:
!Screen Shot 2015-02-13 at 11.51.28.png|thumbnail!


h6.workaround
- Remove the HipChat Post Function from the transition;
- manually execute the transition - it will send the notification as expected.
fields.summary: Triggered transitions fail if they have a HipChat post function

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Software Server*. Using *JIRA Software Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSWCLOUD-14039].
  {panel}

For a repository is large and had many activities (such as creating branches, creating tags, pushing commits, commenting on issues), after first adding it, only recent pull requests are synchronized and show up on the pull request details dialog on the view issue page. Older pull requests after certain time never show up.

This also happens when you have such a large repository added for a while, and does a full synchronization.

The cause of the problem is that the DVCS Connector uses the [GitHub repository events api|https://developer.github.com/v3/activity/events/#list-repository-events] to pull down historical events about pull requests. But this api has a limit of only returning up to 300 events at most. This would limit the synchronization to retrieving at most up to 300 pull requests, assuming all events are about pull requests. In practice, this number is much lower as not all events are for pull requests and even for those that are, not all of them are for pull request creation.

Just as an example, on one repository, only 60 out of 300 events are for pull requests:
{noformat}
 117     "type": "PushEvent",
  80     "type": "IssueCommentEvent",
  60     "type": "PullRequestEvent",
  24     "type": "CreateEvent",
  19     "type": "DeleteEvent",
{noformat}
And only 30 out of the 60 pull request events are for opening a new pull request.
fields.summary: Old GitHub pull requests do not show up after full synchronization

fields.description:
When trying to link a github account I get a 404 error from github.

1. Register application on Github.

---- Use <myorg>.atlassian.com as url and callback url

---- Obtain secret and OAuth Key

2. From Jira use Link BitBucket or Github account

---- Fill in key and secret.

---- Fill in my organization account name from github (also tried with my personal account name)

---- Click Add

--> I see a 404 error page from github.com.

I researched and found several similar sounding problems/questions, but each of them seemed to have a different problem and their solutions did not work for me.

Further research:

Jira OnDemand does a GET to https://github.com/oauth/authorize

It passes parameters scope, client_id, redirect_uri as required per github documentation.

It DOES NOT pass parameter state which appears to be required per github documentation.

The redirect_uri that is passed is

https://mscmobile.atlassian.net/secure/admin/AddOrganizationProgressAction!default.jspa?...

Lots of parameters included after the ?.

The home url and callback url defined at github are https://mscmobile.atlassian.net/

Have tried variations on this, adding to the path, removing the /, etc.

So far the result is always the cute github 404 page.

Questions:

1. Does this break because the state parameter is not sent? Appears to be required by Github.
2. Does it matter that the redirect_uri is passed with the long string of query string parameters instead of just the part preceeding the ? (as shown in documentation)?

I see previous bugs reported, closed, but whatever resolution is there is not working for me. I left this on Answers for 24 hours, with no response.

fields.description:
The Development panel is loaded but when clicking on Branches or Pull Requests detail, the following error is displayed:
{quote}
*Unable to retrieve branch information*
JIRA is having difficulty contacting Bitbucket. If this condition persists, please contact your JIRA administrators.
{quote}
Commits and Builds details work as expected.

JIRA logs display the error message:
{noformat}
2015-01-06 11:12:49,814 TP-Processor201 WARN user 672x272622x1 14vrgxb 111.11.111.110,115.211.116.215 /rest/dev-status/1.0/issue/detail [plugin.devstatus.provider.DefaultCoordinator] Requests failed: Bitbucket (timeout after 10000ms, not getting from cache)
{noformat}

*Cause:*
The DVCS connector times out before retrieving all details.
When clicking on details on issues with fewer branches or pull requests, it loads correctly.

Affected version on Atlassian Cloud:
JIRA DVCS Connector Plugin 2.2.9-D20141204T035127

*Workaround:*
There is no workaround at the moment.

There are performance improvements on the DVCS connector currently being developed that should improve this functionality.

The SQL in question is:
{code}
SELECT COMMIT.ID,COMMIT.* FROM dbo.AO_E8B6CC_COMMIT COMMIT JOIN dbo.AO_E8B6CC_PR_TO_COMMIT PR_TO_COMMIT ON COMMIT.ID = PR_TO_COMMIT.COMMIT_ID JOIN dbo.AO_E8B6CC_PULL_REQUEST PR ON PR_TO_COMMIT.REQUEST_ID = PR.ID WHERE COMMIT.DOMAIN_ID = ? AND PR.ID = ? AND COMMIT.NODE = ?
{code}

{{COMMIT}} is obviously a reserved keyword and MS SQL Server does not like it to be an alias.

h3. Impacts

Pull requests are not synchronized.

Commits and branches are still synchronized.

fields.description:
Since the DVCS connector has admin access to the ondemand team, it could be useful to expose the invitations sent to users and not yet accepted inside JIRA. This would allow administrators of the JIRA instance the ability to see the pending invitations and more clearly understand that is how things are working. In the case of OnDemand, this could also enable self-service resending of AOD invites so that support and customer service doens't have to. [~justen.stepka@atlassian.com] I'd love your input on this.

Invitations should be accessible through the API

Then usually the sync reports something like "Sync Finished: Synchronized 2415 changesets, found 68 matching JIRA issues"

fields.description:
The rest call to find out the status of a sync fails if the logged in user does not have project admin permission for the given project.

The reason this is a problem is the administrators group is not added to the administrators role of created projects.  The permission check in RootResource.getRepository fails.  You need to allow access to this resource if any of the following is true:

* Has PROJECT_ADMIN on the project
* Has Global "JIRA Administrators"
fields.summary: On Studio, Sync Status fails for Non-Project admin
